title: 103_hr5030
content: The Act titled "International Narcotics Control Corrections Act of 1994" makes amendments to the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended regarding the use of herbicides for aerial eradication and definitions related to major illicit drug producing countries. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to include definitions related to major illicit drug producing countries, such as the cultivation or harvesting of illicit coca or cannabis exceeding certain thresholds, and the definition of 'precursor chemical' as per the Controlled Substances Act. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to include definitions related to major illicit drug producing countries and advance notification of transfer of seized assets for narcotics control purposes. The President must notify congressional committees 10 days prior to any transfer of seized property or funds to a foreign country for narcotics control. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to include provisions to halt illicit drug production or trafficking. Section 486 is amended to provide assistance under the Act instead of security assistance. Section 487 is amended to prohibit assistance to drug traffickers. Section 489 is amended to include reporting requirements. Section 489 of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended for fiscal year 1995. Changes include adjusting deadlines and reorganizing subsections. Section 489 of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended for fiscal year 1995, including changes to deadlines and subsection reorganization. Section 489A is also amended to reflect the new fiscal year. Annual certification procedures under Section 490 are updated for fiscal year 1995. Section 489 of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended for fiscal year 1995, with changes to deadlines and subsection reorganization. This includes adjustments to subsections (a)(2), (c), (d), and (g) regarding deadlines, maintenance of licit production, and prevention of illicit activities. For fiscal year 1995, amendments are made to Section 489 of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. Changes include reorganizing subsections and adjusting deadlines. Section 490A is also amended to reflect the changes for the same fiscal year. Amendments are made to Section 489 of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 for fiscal year 1995, including reorganizing subsections and adjusting deadlines. Section 490A is also amended to reflect the changes for the same fiscal year. In subsection (g), the year is changed from 1994 to 1995. SEC. 3. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS TO OTHER LAWS. Amendments are made to various laws such as the Export-Import Bank Act, Title 18 of the U.S. Code, the Tariff Act of 1930, and the Controlled Substances Act by replacing specific sections with new definitions. SEC. 4. REPEAL OF OBSOLETE PROVISIONS. SEC. 4. REPEAL OF OBSOLETE PROVISIONS. The International Narcotics Control Acts of 1992, 1988, and 1986 are repealed, except for certain sections. For fiscal year 1995, exemptions are granted for transfers of excess defense articles, funds for the Foreign Military Financing Program used for narcotics-related purposes, and international military education and training provided for narcotics-related purposes. The President must notify Congress at least 15 days before any transfer or obligation of funds. Assistance provided under this section must be coordinated with international narcotics control assistance. The President is required to notify Congress before any transfer or obligation of funds. SEC. 6. Waiver of restrictions for narcotics-related economic assistance in fiscal year 1995, allowing assistance under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 without usual restrictions if the President notifies Congress 15 days before obligating funds. SEC. 7. Authority for anticrime assistance. SEC. 7. AUTHORITY FOR ANTICRIME ASSISTANCE. The President is authorized to provide assistance to countries or international organizations for the prevention and suppression of international criminal activities, including narcotics trafficking and corruption. Waiver of prohibition of police training under certain conditions. SEC. 8. ASSISTANCE TO DRUG TRAFFICKERS. The President will ensure that relatives and business partners of individuals involved in drug trafficking are not allowed entry into the United States.
